title: Should you trust unanimous decisions? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox of unanimity in the context of a police lineup?

options.label: A
options.text: The more witnesses who agree on a suspect, the more reliable the result is.

options.label: B
options.text: The closer you get to total agreement, the less reliable the result becomes.

options.label: C
options.text: A unanimous verdict is always the most reliable outcome.

options.label: D
options.text: A majority vote is always the best way to determine guilt.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it natural to think that more consensus is a good thing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is always the most reliable outcome.

options.label: B
options.text: Because much of our society relies on majority vote and consensus.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the most efficient way to make decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the only way to ensure accuracy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to understanding the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: Considering the overall level of uncertainty involved in the situation.

options.label: B
options.text: Ignoring the overall level of uncertainty involved in the situation.

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing solely on the number of people in agreement.

options.label: D
options.text: Disregarding the type of situation you're dealing with.

multiple-choice.question: What would you expect if you tossed a coin one hundred times?

options.label: A
options.text: To get heads 100% of the time.

options.label: B
options.text: To get tails 100% of the time.

options.label: C
options.text: To get heads somewhere around 50% of the time.

options.label: D
options.text: To get tails somewhere around 75% of the time.

multiple-choice.question: According to a 1994 study, what percentage of witnesses tend to pick the wrong person out of a lineup?
Why does a unanimous identification start to seem less like certain guilt?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the most reliable outcome.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is the most efficient way to determine guilt.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it may indicate a systemic error or bias in the lineup.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the only way to ensure accuracy.

multiple-choice.question: What was the cause of the consistent DNA evidence in the case of the Phantom of Heilbronn?

options.label: A
options.text: The DNA samples were deliberately contaminated by the police.

options.label: B
options.text: The cotton swabs used to collect the DNA samples were accidentally contaminated by a woman working in the swab factory.

options.label: C
options.text: The DNA samples were collected from the wrong crime scenes.

options.label: D
options.text: The DNA samples were analyzed incorrectly.

multiple-choice.question: What was the claimed turnout and result of the presidential referendum held by Saddam Hussein in 2002?
When is unanimous agreement theoretically ideal?

options.label: A
options.text: In cases where you'd expect high odds of variability and uncertainty.

options.label: B
options.text: In cases where you'd expect very low odds of variability and uncertainty.

options.label: C
options.text: In cases where you'd expect moderate odds of variability and uncertainty.

options.label: D
options.text: In cases where you'd expect no variability or uncertainty.

multiple-choice.question: What should a perfect result that seems too good to be true indicate?

options.label: C
options.text: That there's probably some hidden factor affecting the system.

title: Why the insect brain is so incredible - Anna Stöckl

multiple-choice.question: What did Charles Darwin find more impressive than the human brain?
Who assumed insects had no brains at all in his project to classify and describe all living things?
What is unique about an insect's nervous system compared to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: It works like a monarchy with the brain calling the shots

options.label: B
options.text: It works like a decentralized federation with clusters of neurons coordinating activities

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of an insect's brain in its survival?

options.label: A
options.text: Only to perceive the world through sight

options.label: C
options.text: To perceive the world through sight and smell, choose suitable mates, remember locations of food sources and hives, regulate communication, and coordinate navigation

multiple-choice.question: How many neurons does an insect's brain have compared to humans?
What is the phenomenon called when different species evolve similar brain structures despite having different evolutionary paths?
Why are scientists fascinated by insect brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Only because of their small size

options.label: C
options.text: Because their small size and simplicity make it easier to understand how neurons work together in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not closely related to humans

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the applications of studying insect brains in engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Designing control systems for self-flying airplanes

options.label: B
options.text: Designing control systems for tiny search-and-rescue roach bots

options.label: C
options.text: Designing control systems for self-driving cars

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the human nervous system and the insect nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: The human nervous system is decentralized, while the insect nervous system is centralized

options.label: B
options.text: The human nervous system is centralized, while the insect nervous system is decentralized

options.label: C
options.text: The human nervous system has more neurons, while the insect nervous system has fewer neurons

options.label: D
options.text: The human nervous system has fewer neurons, while the insect nervous system has more neurons

multiple-choice.question: What can scientists understand by studying the comparison between insect and human brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Only which brain functions are unique to humans

options.label: B
options.text: Only which brain functions are general solutions to evolutionary problems

options.label: C
options.text: Both which brain functions are unique to humans and which are general solutions to evolutionary problems

options.label: D
options.text: Neither which brain functions are unique to humans nor which are general solutions to evolutionary problems

title: What is Minimalist Art And Why Does it Matter?

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following artists is known for his work with fluorescent tubes?
What art movement did minimalism reject?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a sense of emotional connection

options.label: C
options.text: To dismantle the separation between the viewer and the art

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sense of distance and detachment

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of minimalist art, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Use of bright colors and complex compositions

options.label: B
options.text: Emphasis on emotional expression and personal gesture

options.label: C
options.text: Use of industrial materials and machine-made forms

options.label: D
options.text: Reference to historical or cultural narratives

multiple-choice.question: Who is the artist that said, "It is best that the basic unit be deliberately uninteresting"?
What is the term that was initially used to describe the art movement that later became known as minimalism?
According to the transcript, what is the effect of minimalist art on the viewer's perception of space and their own body?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of disorientation and confusion

options.label: B
options.text: It encourages the viewer to ignore their surroundings

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the viewer aware of their own body and position in the room

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a sense of detachment from the physical space

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a way in which minimalist art challenges traditional notions of art, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: By emphasizing the importance of technical skill and craftsmanship

options.label: B
options.text: By creating a sense of illusion or deception

options.label: C
options.text: By rejecting the idea that art should be expressive or emotional

options.label: D
options.text: By emphasizing the role of the artist as a creator of meaning

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between the meaning of minimalist art and the context in which it is viewed?

options.label: A
options.text: The meaning is fixed and inherent in the object itself

options.label: B
options.text: The meaning is determined by the artist's intentions

options.label: C
options.text: The meaning is created by the viewer's interpretation

options.label: D
options.text: The meaning exists in the context and interaction with the viewer

title: How do schools of fish swim in harmony? - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is emergence in the context of complex systems?

options.label: A
options.text: The creation of complex behaviors and functions through deliberate coordination

options.label: B
options.text: The spontaneous creation of sophisticated behaviors and functions from large groups of simple elements

options.label: C
options.text: The breakdown of complex systems into individual components

options.label: D
options.text: The study of individual elements in a complex system

multiple-choice.question: Why do fish swim in schools?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they enjoy each other's company

multiple-choice.question: What are the two basic rules that individual fish follow in a school?

options.label: A
options.text: Stay close to the shark and keep swimming

options.label: B
options.text: Stay close, but not too close to your neighbor, and keep swimming

options.label: C
options.text: Follow the leader and stay alert

options.label: D
options.text: Swim in a random pattern and avoid collisions

multiple-choice.question: What happens when enough fish join a group following the right set of local rules?

options.label: A
options.text: The movement of individual fish becomes more chaotic

options.label: B
options.text: The school becomes controlled by a single fish

options.label: C
options.text: The movement of individual fish is eclipsed by an entirely new entity: the school

options.label: D
options.text: The fish start to swim in a random pattern

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of emergence in a non-living system?

options.label: B
options.text: The movement of a school of fish

options.label: C
options.text: The growth of a city's economy

options.label: D
options.text: The behavior of a single neuron

multiple-choice.question: Why can't emergence be understood by simply taking it apart?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a complex system with many interacting elements

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a simple system with few interacting elements

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a living system

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a non-living system

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: To either excite or inhibit other neurons

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: The system becomes less chaotic and more predictable

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of emergent phenomena at vastly different scales?

options.label: A
options.text: That emergence requires someone or something to be in charge

options.label: B
options.text: That emergence doesn't require someone or something to be in charge

options.label: C
options.text: That emergence is only found in living systems

options.label: D
options.text: That emergence is only found in non-living systems

options.label: A
options.text: The behavior of a single neuron

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
